metadata.title: Burn Rehabilitation  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: occupational therapy: burns, full-thickness,  rehabilitation, occupational therapy burn rehabilitation: epidermal
anatomical location body part affected: A burn may affect any part of the body; burns to the body are measured by percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) and the depth of the burn
description: A burn is an injury to the skin (and sometimes the muscles and bone) as the result of fire/flame, scalding, electricity, radiation, chemicals, tar, grease, sunburn, and/or skin disease (such as Stevens-Johnson  syndrome)(1,39) ICD-10  codes
reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Burns are classified according to the depth of injury.(1,2,3)The extent of injury, patient age, and any associated illness or injuries are also important considerations.(3)Presenting signs and symptoms of burn injuries are directly related to the depth of the injury(1)

Epidermal burn (first-degree  burn)(1,21) –Causes cell damage to the superficial layers of the epidermis –Skin appears red or erythematous and dry –Blisters are absent but slight edema may be noted –Includes sunburns and superficial scalds(6) –The area will become tender after a delay and then heal on its own with no scar tissue formation

Superficial partial-thickness  burn (second-degree  burn)(1) –Affects the epidermis and superficial dermis, resulting in blistering(1,4) –Burn site will be moist/weeping; blanches with pressure; painful to the touch(1) –Re-epithelialization  in 7–20  days(1) with minimal scarring(21)

Deep partial-thickness  burn (deep second-degree  burn)(1) –Affects the epidermis, superficial dermis, and skin appendages(1) (e.g., hair, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, and nails) –May result in loss of sensation and apocrine gland (sweat gland) function at the burn site(1) –No blisters; wet or waxy dry appearance with variable color(1) –This type of burn is less painful to the touch due to the loss of some sensation(1) –At risk of conversion to full-thickness  burn due to marginal blood supply to the area(1) –Re-epithelialization  in weeks to months; may benefit from skin grafting to speed recovery(1) –Scar tissue may develop weeks to months after initial injury; the development of scar tissue is referred to as hypertrophic scarring(1) -Hypertrophic scarring is often painful and can interfere with joint function(1)

Full-thickness  burn (third-degree  burn)(1) –Affects the entire epidermal and dermal layers of the skin(1) -May also result in damage to underlying tissue(6) –Results in complete loss of skin appendages, sensation, and apocrine function(1) –Large full-thickness  burns may impair the body’s ability to regulate body temperature(1)  –If the burn extends to the nerve endings of the dermal layer, neuropathic-like  pain and pruritus (itching) may result(1) –May be anywhere from white waxy to leathery gray to charred black in appearance(1) –No pain due to complete damage of the nerve endings; does not blanch to pressure(1) –Requires skin grafting as re-epithelialization  does not occur(1,4) –Hypertrophic scarring can occur in the weeks or months after initial injury, which is often painful and can interfere with joint function(1)

Subdermal burn (fourth-degree  burn)(21) –Charred, black skin (eschar), exposed fat or deep tissue(1) –Affects muscle, tendon, and bone(1) –Always requires medical treatment, including amputation or extensive deep debridement(1,4)

Burn-associated  complications –Joint contractures(1,4,39) -Contractures of the hand most commonly occur at the wrist(1) –Heterotopic ossification (the development of bone in abnormal areas, usually in soft tissues)(1,4) -Patients with burns greater than 20% TBSA are highly susceptible(21) -Can occur anywhere but most commonly affected area is elbow, followed by hips and shoulders(21) –Pathological scarring(21) -Hypertrophic -Contracture –Neuropathy(1,21) -Most common sites are brachial plexus, ulnar nerve, and common peroneal nerve(21) –Amputation(1,3,4) –Infection(1,6,21) –Fluid and electrolyte imbalances(6) –Dehydration(1) –Gastrointestinal complications(6) –Malnutrition(1,4) –Pulmonary complications(6,21) –Metabolic complications(21) –Cardiovascular complications(6,21) –Impaired thermoregulation(1,6) –Psychiatric complications -Depression(1) -Anxiety(1) -Sleep disturbances(1) -PTSD(1) -Behavioral changes -The authors of a qualitative study exploring the changes experienced by adult females following a burn injury found that the presence of visible scarring or disfigurement resulted in altered behavior with regard to socialization and sexuality(23) –Specific complications associated with electrical burns:(21) -Cardiac arrhythmias -Acute renal failure -Acute spinal cord damage -Vertebral fracture  -Ventricular fibrillation -Respiratory arrest Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: It is important that the patient be medically stable prior to participating in occupational therapy; however, whenever possible, the occupational therapist (OT) should complete the initial evaluation within 24 to 48 hours of admission to acute care(2)

causes: the following can cause burn in: Flame/fire(1,5)–Most burns in adults result from fire or flame injuries(1)
Electrical current(3,39)–Including high-  or low-voltage  electricity and lightning strikes(1,3)

Hot liquids (including water, soup, coffee, tea, hot chocolate, etc.)(5,39)–The most common cause of burn injury in children aged 1 to 5 years is scalds from hot liquids(21)–The primary cause of burn injury in adolescents is also accidents with hot liquids(21)
pathogenesis:: Any type of burn causes skin damage, and in some cases underlying tissue damage; burns originate and developthrough contact with an external environmental cause or internally as a result of skin disease (such as Stevens-Johnsonsyndrome).(1) The amount of skin destruction or depth of burn injury is based on temperature of the burn source and thelength of time the tissue is exposed to heat(6,21)

Functions of layers of the skin:(21)–Epidermis: the outermost layer; provides protection from infection and waterproofing–Dermis: the deeper layer; contains blood vessels, lymphatics, nerves, collagen, and elastic fibers and gives skin its tensilestrength and elasticity-It also encloses the epidermal appendages: sweat ducts, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles–Skin is also important in temperature regulation, secretion of oils, and vitamin D synthesis and it contributes to cosmeticappearance and identity

Electrical burns:(21)–Vary based on the type of current, intensity of the current, and the area of the body the current passes through–Tissue damage results from the resistance to the passage of the current or by direct electrical current–Typically, the patient will present with two contact sites: where the patient first came into contact with the current andwhere he or she was grounded

Burn wound zones:(6,21)–Zone of coagulation: innermost area of wound; cells are irreversibly damaged and cell death occurs–Zone of stasis: middle area of wound; injured cells that may die within 24–48  hours without diligent treatment(whereinfection, drying, and/or inadequate perfusion will convert potentially salvageable tissue to necrotic tissue)–Zone of hyperemia: outermost area of wound; site of minimal cell damage; the tissue should recover within several dayswith no lasting effects

Wound healing:(21)–Epidermal healing:-Epithelial healing can occur if there are viable cells lining the skin appendages-Epithelial growth is stimulated by exposed subepithelial tissue and involves the migration of cells in an attempt to coverthe exposed wound-The cells stop migrating when they are completely in contact with other epithelial cells, called contact inhibition-After contact inhibition, the cells can begin to differentiate to form the various epithelial layers–Dermal healing (scar formation):-Inflammatory phase:-Prepares the wound for healing; begins immediately, lasts about 3 to 5 days, and is characterized by redness, edema,warmth, pain, and decreased ROM-Proliferative phase:-Re-epithelization  is occurring at the surface of the wound, while deep within the wound fibroblasts (the cells thatsynthesize scar tissue) are migrating and proliferating-Collagen is deposited with random alignment; stress applied to developing tissue during this time causes the fibers toalign along the direction of the force and the tensile strength of the wound increases-Granulation tissue is also formed during this phase; excess granulation tissue may lead to an increase in hypertrophicscarring-Wound contraction occurs, during which the body actively attempts to close a wound-Maturation phase:-Remodeling of the scar tissue-During this phase, there is a reduction in the number of fibroblasts, a decrease in vascularity, and remodeling ofcollagen-The ratio of collagen breakdown to production determines the scar that forms-If the rate of breakdown equals or exceeds the rate of production, a pale, flat, pliable scar results-If the rate of production exceeds breakdown, then a hypertrophic scar may result
risk factors: Age: Older adults and children (especially those aged 1 to 5 years) are at greatest risk(5)–The thinner skin of young children and older adults increases their risk of deeper burns with more complications(6)
Smoking while home oxygen tank is in use(5)

overall contraindications precautions: ROM, exercise, and ambulation should not be performed directly following specific skin grafting surgeries; follow physician’s orders regarding the start of ROM/strengthening exercises and ambulation after a grafting procedure(1)

If the patient has deep partial-  or full-thickness  dorsal hand burns, boutonnière precautions should be followed until the integrity of the hand’s extensor hood mechanisms can be confirmed. Boutonnière precautions involve preventing the composite active or passive flexion of the fingers; isolated metacarpal-phalangeal  flexion must be combined with interphalangeal (IP) joint extension. These precautions are intended to avoid stress and damage to a potentially compromised extensor tendon mechanism. Any passive proximal interphalangeal (PIP) flexion should be avoided; protective splinting/ orthosis use might be appropriate to maintain the PIP joins in extension(2)
Burns can cause significant changes in fluid loss, edema levels, blood pressure, pulse, respiratory status, and oxygen levels; stop treatment and report to physician immediately(6)

Regular bathing of unburned areas and frequent bed linen changes are also important infection-control  measures;(6) follow facility policies regarding the prevention of infection Wash hands for at least 15 seconds between patients(7) Ensure cleanliness of all therapy equipment used with the patient(6) Signs of infection(6) –Increased redness –Swelling –Drainage –Foul odor
Report signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT; e.g., swelling, warmth, redness in the leg/s) to physician immediately
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: It is important that the patient be medically stable prior to participating in occupational therapy; however, whenever possible, the occupational therapist (OT) should complete the initial evaluation within 24 to 48 hours of admission to acute care(2)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: What is the cause, extent, location, and depth of the burn? Have there been any medical complications thus far? If so, what type of complications and what interventions have been provided? -Review the patient’s medical history

course of treatment.medical management: Did the patient’s burn require medical intervention? Was the patient treated for any coexisting complications (e.g., anoxia or shock) or injuries (e.g., fracture)? Surgical intervention may include skin grafting, amputation, surgical contracture release, surgical resection of heterotopic bone, reconstructive surgery, debridement, primary excision, escharotomy (incision[s] through the burned tissue of fullthickness  burns to reduce edema and relieve pressure), escharectomy (scar tissue removal), fasciotomy (a procedure to relieve pressure and prevent tissue death), or amputation(1,3,21)surgical removal of eschar(21) Autograft (patient’s own skin), allograft (skin from another living person or cadaver), xenograft (skin from another species), skin substitutes (cultured skin grown in a laboratory)(21) Split-thickness  skin graft (contains epidermis and dermis); full-thickness  skin graft (full dermis thickness)(21) Correction of scar contracture may require surgery if therapy interventions are unsuccessful(21) Radiation therapy may be effective for treatment of heterotopic ossification(1)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Does the patient feel that the pain and other symptoms are being adequately controlled? Common medicationsUse for up to one year could increase muscle protein synthesis and weight gain and reduce hospital length of stay(1) Antibiotics to prevent or treat infection of the burn(1) Antihistamines for pruritus(1) NSAIDs for pain and inflammation(1) Pain management medications (e.g., opiates, morphine)(1) Tetanus prophylaxis(1,3) Topical creams(1,4) Gabapentin for pruritus(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Review results of any diagnostic tests
Triple phase bone scan can be used to diagnose heterotopic ossification(1)
Chest X-ray  and bronchoscopy to evaluate inhalation injuries(1,6)
MRI/head CT scan (for patients with cognitive impairments due to anoxia)(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help  Alternative therapies may include massage, distraction, biofeedback, music therapy, art therapy, hypnosis, guidedimagery  relaxation therapy,(1) and peer support groups/organizations(6)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location of burns; determine TBSA affected by using the rule of 9s(3,6)(3,6) -9% for the head and neck -4.5% for anterior head/neck -4.5% for posterior head/neck -9% for each upper extremity -4.5% for anterior portion of the arm -4.5% for posterior portion of the arm -18% for each lower extremity -9% for anterior portion of the leg -9% for posterior portion of the leg -9% for the anterior upper torso -9% for the posterior upper torso -9% for the anterior lower torso -9% for the posterior lower torso -1% for the genitalia -There are specific charts that are used to calculate TBSA in children based on age; sometimes the rule of 9s is modified, taking 9% from the legs and adding it to the head of a child who is under age 1year, then adding back 1% to the legs until the age of 9 years, when the head is in the same proportion relative to the body as it is in adults. Beginning at the age of 9, the rule of 9s for children is used to calculate TBSA in the same way as it is for adults
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -At the time of injury, the patient may have experienced a burning sensation, severe pain at injury site, and possibly numbness due to nerve damage(1) -Post-injury  complications include hypertrophic scarring, decreased muscle strength and ROM, pruritus, poor thermoregulation, heterotopic ossification, contractures, joint deformities, neuropathy, amputation at burn site, wound sepsis, edema(1,4,6,21,39)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Ask the patient to rate his or her symptoms, including pain and pruritus (i.e., severe itching) -Significant pain occurs in first-  and second-degree burns. Allow the patient to state when the pain level is too high to continue with treatment; utilize simple pain scales to assist in determining pain level throughout evaluation and treatment sessions(1) -A patient with a third-degree  burn is often unable to feel pain initially due to the burning of nerve endings;(1) special attention should be paid to physical changes, as the individual may not be able to express pain level; for this reason, increased awareness and sensitivity regarding the intensity and length of treatment on the part of the OT is required -Visual analog scale (V AS) -McGill Pain Questionnaire -Burn Specific Pain Anxiety Scale (BSPAS) -010  pain scale -Oucher or FLACC scale for children or nonverbal patients -5-D itch scale(22) -Itch severity scale
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -Changes in symptoms may include increased edema or changes in blood pressure -Inquire about the proper fitting of any orthoses, whether they irritate the burn area, and if there are any differences at different times of day/night
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Sleep disturbance is common in patients with burn injuries(1,6)  -Document number of awakenings/night; include reason for waking, such as physical pain or psychosocial reasons (e.g., nightmares)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician -Cardiac arrhythmia (primarily after electrical burns)(3,4,21) -Fractures, especially cervical spine fractures, may result from an electrical burn if the victim is thrown a distance by the current(4)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Smoke inhalation or other inhalation injury related to flame burns may lead to intubation, use of mechanical ventilator, decreased endurance level, and pulmonary edema(1,26) -Direct trauma to the upper airway can also occur from the inhalation of hot gases.(21) Does the patient require supplemental oxygen and/or other supportive breathing device?Assess the patient’s psychosocial status -Patients with burn injuries often develop psychosocial complications and require significant psychosocial support throughout the remainder of their lives(1,6) -PTSD is common in patients with burn injuries(1) -How does the patient relate to his or her surroundings? Is the patient overly emotional, anxious, fearful, etc.? -Coping with Burns Questionnaire(24) -Satisfaction with Appearance Scale(25) -If there are concerns regarding the patient’s psychosocial status and he or she is not currently under the care of a psychiatrist or other mental health professional, a referral for further workup may be appropriateNote patient’s hearing abilities, especially if the burn injury affects the head and neck -Does the patient require frequent repetition of questions? -Does the patient speak loudly even in close, quiet conversational environments? -If the patient appears to have impaired hearing, refer to audiology for further workup Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient had any previous burn injuries? If so, what complications or scar tissue resulted from this injury?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient and/or caregiver about other problems, including substance abuse, cognitive impairment, diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders For pediatric patients, inquire about development and achievement of milestones up to the point of injury Complications that can arise from extended intensive care/hospital stays include pulmonary dysfunction, renal failure, sepsis, spinal cord injury, peripheral nerve damage, cognitive impairment due to anoxia, generalized deconditioning, and malnutrition(1,4)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: -Is the patient employed? -If so, what skills are required on a daily basis for the job? -Does the patient have special accommodations in order to perform his or her job?  -What leisure activities does the patient enjoy? For example, does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports, drama, music, photography?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -What level of assistance does the patient currently require with ADLs at home, at school, and/or in the community? -Does the patient use a walker, wheelchair, leg braces, etc., for ambulation? -Does the patient wear orthotic devices? -Does the patient require adaptive equipment for ADLs? -Does the patient require/wear glasses or contacts? -Does the patient use an alternative or augmentative communication (AAC) device?
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -With whom (spouse, parents, children, siblings, grandparents, caregivers, etc.) does the patient live? Are they able to provide the necessary support? -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -Inquire about the levels of the home, including stairs, numbers of floors, etc.

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices –Mobility aids -Cane -Walker -Wheelchair -Crutches -Hemi-walker -Ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs) –Toileting equipment -Grab bars next to the toilet -Bedside commode -Urinal at bedside -Raised toilet seat -Elevated foot rest at the toilet
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance reactions –Tinetti Balance Scale(10) –Functional Reach Test –Berg Balance Scale
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Patients with burn injuries may have reduced cardiorespiratory function as a complication of smoke inhalation(6,21)
Assess vitals before, during, and after activity, including heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and perceived rate of exertion
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Note increased edema in the burn area as well as nonburned areas, changes in blood pressure or pulse rate(6) –Report significant changes in edema, blood pressure, or pulse, or signs and symptoms of DVT (e.g., swelling, warmth, redness in the leg/s) to physician immediately Edema –Circumferential measurements  –Assess presence and severity of edema(2) –Follow positioning guidelines to reduce edema (e.g., elevating affected extremity above heart level to reduce distal edema formation)(2)Assess bed mobility and transfers to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity –Test static and dynamic activities –Timed Up & Go (TUG) test(11) – a measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seated position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, which are all important for independent mobility –FIM – an 18-item,  7-level  ordinal scale(12)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted) –If the patient has impaired gait, referral to physical therapy may be appropriateHypertrophic scarring often results in reduced joint mobility over time in patients with burn injuries(1,4,39) –Joint contractures can result in deformity as well as loss of ROM(39) -Vancouver Scar Scale (VSS)(21) -Hamilton Scale with photography for evaluating scars(8) -Matching Assessment of Scars and Photographs (MAPS)(8) -Patient and Observer Scar Assessment Scale (POSAS)(8) Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) -Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test(8,13) -Michigan Hand Outcome Questionnaire(8) –Note patient’s hand dominance prior to the injury(2)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength in affected areas; long-term  hospitalization in patients with burn injuries may result in generalized deconditioning(1) –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT on muscles with contractures or abnormal tone and coordination(8) –Dynamometer to evaluate hand strength bilaterally –Assess pinch strength with pinch meterAssess as indicated and appropriate for pediatric patients –Peabody Developmental Motor Scales (PDMS-2)
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect for proper wear of all braces/orthoses and compression devices; improper wear can lead to compression neuropathies (most common site is the peroneal nerve); splinting and casting can cause pressure sores(1) •Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations): Note the patient’s vision and hearing, especially if the burn injury includes the face and/or neck
If during the exam it appears as though the patient has altered perception, refer to audiology, ophthalmology, or neurology for further testing
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Patients with burn injuries will likely have impaired ROM in the joints of the affected area.(2,39) Respect patient’s pain tolerance when assessing ROM –Measure active ROM (AROM) and passive ROM (PROM) using a goniometer –If one side remains intact, compare to nonaffected side –Note if the patient is using compensatory strategies at the fingers, wrist, elbow, shoulder, or trunk Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing)brushing teeth, combing hair, dressing upper and lower extremities, clothing management, toileting, applying makeup or shaving the face, bathing, eating  –For community-dwelling  and other high-functioning  patients, assess IADLs such as driving (car transfers), meal preparation, shopping, and housework –The FIM, Barthel Activities of Daily Living Index, and Modified Barthel Index (MBI) are appropriate standardized measures for ADLs(8,12) –The Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) evaluates function through evaluation at baseline and status throughout treatment, utilizing injured individual’s direct input in scale(8) –The Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (AMPS) scores patient’s ability to perform specific tasks on assessment, scored again at different times in treatment, requires specific training to perform assessment(8) –For children with burn injuries, the WeeFIM is appropriate for assessment of ADLs(14) -The WeeFIM assesses basic daily living and functional skills in children from birth to 7 years of age(14)self-care, sphincter control, transfers, locomotion, communication, and social cognition(14) –Splints/orthoses and compression garments can impede fine or gross motor coordination, possibly limiting the individual’s ability to perform showering/dressing tasks or simple meal prep –Patient might benefit from use of adaptive equipment (e.g., long-handled  shoe horn, sock aid, or dressing stick) to increase independence in ADLs when one arm is limited in either fine or gross motor coordination because of splints/ orthoses, compression garments, joint contractures, hypertrophic scarring, or additional limitations resulting from the burn injury
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Perform a sensory screening of all sensory distribution areas,(2) including touch sensation as well as spatial awareness and olfactory sensation; sensation is affected in patients with deep partial-thickness,  full-thickness,  and subdermal burns(1) –Tests for touch sensation include normal touch, light touch, pinprick, position sensation, vibration, and temperature –The Moberg Pick-Up  Test uses functional tasks to assess hand sensation(13) –The Weinstein Enhanced Sensory Test (WEST) or Semmes-Weinstein  monofilaments are measures of cutaneous sensation (e.g., light touch)(8)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –The QuickDASH Outcome Measure is a subjective measure of upper extremity function following burns(15)burn injuries typically have a negative impact on quality of life; the extent of this impact should be evaluated(16) -The Short Form-36  (SF-36)  evaluates overall independence, emotional and mental health, limitations to previous roles, and social status(8) -The Burn Specific Health Scale (BSHS) evaluates overall quality of life issues including pain, function, and psychological issues(8,16) -The EQ-5D  evaluates overall health-related  quality of life over 12-month  time period through individual report(17,18) –Pain assessments -V AS(8) -McGill Pain Questionnaire(8) -BSPAS(8) -Brief Pain Inventory (BPI)(8) -OSBD-revised  Procedural Behavior Rating Scale for children(19) -Oucher self-report  evaluation (ages 3–12 years)(19)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE)(9) is appropriate for patients with burn injuries –Anoxia as a result of smoke inhalation can result in cognitive impairment(1) –If the patient appears to have significant cognitive deficits, recommend referral to neuropsychologist, neurologist, or speech-language  pathologist (SLP) for further workup(1)

contraindications precautions: there is abnormal swelling and/or sensation in the extremities(20)
the skin becomes sore or broken(20)

Do not place electrodes near carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads -In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen -In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck
History of miscarriage in pregnant women
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
over the abdominal and lumbar regions during pregnancy
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
in the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
over the carotid arteries, carotid sinus, and vagus and phrenic nerves
Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the  potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Patients with compression garments must be provided with instructions for use and precautions, including contacting the OT or physician if:

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with burn injuries may be appropriate for occupational therapy due to risk of developing joint contractures, scarring that interferes with ROM and functional upper extremity use, decreased function in affected area, pain, and reduced ability to perform ADLs/IADLs and participate in prior functional activities and roles
prognosis: In a study designed to examine return to work intervention strategies for patients sustaining a work-related  burn injury, researchers found that an intervention bundle involving the patient, employer, burn clinic staff, and workers’ compensation was effective in supporting return to work(29) –Data review was completed for 338 patients who sustained a work-related  burn injury and who received care at a regional burn center followed by vocational rehabilitation services; the review was completed over a 5-year  time span  –V ocational rehabilitation services involved an intervention bundle consisting of patient/family education focused on burn recovery, employer education, physician recommendations for workplace accommodations, employee health status letters, and individualized Activity Prescription Forms (APFs) listing activity and/or shift-length  restrictions upon return to work –Results indicated that 93% of the patients returned to work and the average time to return to work was 24 days following initial injury; 30% of the patients required and received workplace accommodations

In a study designed to determine factors that predict health status and hand function of patients with hand burns, researchers found that psychiatric illness, female sex, and need for reconstructive or secondary surgery were associated with poorer outcomes(26) –Study included 41 patients 12–24  months post hand burn –Results of a burn-specific  health status questionnaire (BSHS) indicated that a history of psychiatric illness and female sex were predictors of reduced ratings of general health status; ratings on the body image and ability to work domains were significantly lower among female participants –Results of a hand injury outcome questionnaire (Brief Michigan Hand Outcome Questionnaire) indicated that female sex and need for reconstructive or secondary surgery were associated with more significant deficits in hand function –A shorter hospital length of stay was associated with better outcomes for general health status and hand function

Cognitive status may also be a predictor of rehabilitation outcomes for patients with burn injuries(27) –Researchers who examined the impact of cognitive function on inpatient rehabilitation outcomes for the burn injury population found that greater cognitive function upon admission was associated with improved outcomes –Cognitive function was assessed using the cognitive domain of the FIM, which was administered upon admission and again at discharge from an inpatient rehabilitation facility; FIM score total gain, acute care readmissions, rate of discharge to the community, and length of stay efficiency were other variables studied –Patients with higher cognitive FIM scores upon admission demonstrated the most significant gains with total FIM scores at discharge; higher cognitive FIM scores were also associated with a reduced rate of acute care readmissions and a decreased length of stay efficiency, as these patients spent more time in the rehabilitation facility and not in an acute care setting
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral to speech therapy if the patient has speech, language, cognitive, or swallowing problems Referral to audiology if the patient appears to have a hearing impairment without prior hearing deficit Referral to ophthalmology if vision has been affected Referral to neurology if patient has sensory involvement Referral to nutritionist and wound care nurse is appropriate for all patients with deep partial-thickness,  full-thickness,  or subdermal burn injuries(1) –Enteral feeding may be needed; most burn patients should be under the care of a dietitian
other considerations: Burn rehabilitation takes place over many years, as complications can arise months or years after initial burn injury(1,4)

Patients with burn injuries sometimes benefit from group support.(6) The American Burn Association supports a camp designed by an OT that is specifically for children/teenagers who have had burn injuries

Authors of a 2018 systematic review found that virtual-reality therapy can be an effective method for reducing pain for patients who are concurrently undergoing dressing change or physical therapy treatment. However, further studies are warranted(32) –Based on 13 articles that included 362 burn patients
treatment summary: Joint positioning and/or splinting to prevent contractures, loss of AROM, loss of strength, and loss of joint mobility in the affected area(1,2,4) –OTs create individualized splints/orthoses, perform proper anti-deformity  joint positioning, and begin PROM/AROM based on the patient’s status and physician’s orders(1,4)

Compression garments (also called pressure garments)  –OTs may assist in the creation and implementation of compression garments to provide edema management, decrease scar development, decrease pruritus, and promote desensitization of burned area(1,2,4,20) -Compression garments are made of a material that is 75% nylon and 25% Lycra; each garment is individually created for a specific patient(20) -Ensure the compression garment is comfortable and not too tight; two fingers should fit between the garment and skin -Compression garments should not impede function and should be easy for the patient to don and doff -At least two sets of garments should be provided to the patient -Patients must be re-measured  every 6 weeks and have new garments created -Prophylactic pressure therapy is warranted for patients with the following criteria:(20) -Wound taking 10–14  days to heal in skin that is black due to burn injury -Any wound taking 14–21  days to heal -The patient’s wounds are expected to take longer than 21 days to heal –Compression garments usually are discontinued after scar maturation, approximately 1.5–2  years post injury(1,20) -Patients are instructed to wear the compression garments 23 hours per day, with one 30-minute  break in the morning and one in the evening for cleaning and garment change(20)

Massage –Authors of an RCT study found that massage therapy performed along the hypertrophic scar areas can provide immediate improvement in overall elasticity of the skin; however, there were no long-term  benefits associated with massage in regard to maintaining elasticity and reducingerythema and skin thickness(37) –Aromatherapy massage that utilizes lavender and chamomile aromatic oils can effectively reduce anxiety levels and improve sleep qualityin patients with burns(38)

Inpatient rehabilitation –Researchers found that early initiation of inpatient rehabilitation following treatment at a burn center supported improved functional outcomes and more efficient resource utilization(28) -Researchers completed a retrospective review of data both before and after a rehabilitation center was merged with a trauma center containing a burn unit -FIM scores at admission and discharge from inpatient rehabilitation were used to determine functional outcomes; total waiting time for inpatient rehabilitation, burn center length of stay, rehabilitation length of stay, physical and occupational therapy workload, and discharge destination were used to determine resource utilization -Although the data for all patients (including those transferred to inpatient rehabilitation both before and after the merger) indicated improved total FIM scores, the patients transferred to the rehabilitation center after the merger had shorter burn center length of stay and shorter waiting time for rehabilitation

Exercise –A community-  based exercise program has been shown to improve the cardiopulmonary fitness of adults who have had severe burns compared to usual standard of care(33) -Forty-five  patients with severe burns (TBSA ≥ 30%) were randomized to either the community exercise group (n = 31) or control group (n = 14) -Those in the exercise group received 36 personal training sessions: 3 times weekly for 12 weeks. The program consisted of aerobic and resistance training exercises. Aerobic exercise sessions, including warm-up  and cool-down,  lasted 20 to 40 minutes. Exercises were prescribed based on an intensity rating of 60–85%  of a patient’s peak heart rate or with a rating of perceived exertion score between 6 and 8. Thirty-minute  resistance training sessions consisted of 3 sets of 8–15 repetitions using machines or free weights
Results at the end of 12 weeks showed significant improvement in cardiopulmonary function for those in the exercise group based on VO 2

Leap motion training, which is a form of virtual reality, utilizes biofeedback and trainfine-motor  skills and can be used to improve ROM, decrease scar thickness, and improve hand function in patients experiencing functional impairments from hand burns(34) –The leap motion controller is a device that works on fine-motor  skillsand provides the user withvisual and auditory feedback –The games used in this study—cube grasping, flower petal removal, and balloon or bird shooting—incorporated finger flexion, pinching, and/or finger abduction and adduction  –Sixteen patients were randomized to either the leap motion group (n = 8) or control group (n = 8). The leap motion group performed 40 minutes of occupational therapy, but also received 20 minutes of leap motion training, twice a week for 4 months. The control group received twice-weekly occupational treatment for 60 minutes for the same study period –Results show that after 4 months, the leap motion group demonstrated significant improvements in functional mobility and scar formation

Using low-energy  extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) once a week for at least 4 weeks can reduce pain and pruritus for those still experiencing post-burn  related symptoms(35) –Fifty burned patients were equally randomized to either the ESWT group (n = 25) or placebo group (n = 25). Both groups also received traditional physical therapy treatment –The ESWT group received no more than 10 minutes of ESWT therapy, with settings set as follows: frequency of 4 Hz with total shocks ranging from 1000 to 2000 shocks; probe diameter of 30 mm at 100 shocks per cm2; energy flux density of 0.05–0.20  mJpermm2 –The placebo group received the same parameters, but no electrical output was emitted from the device –Results at the end of 4 weeks showed improved scores on pain rating, 12-item  pruritus severity scale score, and Burn Specific Health Scale–Brief  (BSHS-B)  for those in the ESWT group compared to the placebo group

Authors of a study conducted in Egypt who compared the effects of negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) and microcurrent electrical stimulation (MES) found that NPWT was beneficial for reducing bacterial growth along the wound beds of burns and MES was more effective in decreasing the wound surface area in burn wounds(36) . maintenance or prevention: Prevention of burn injuries includes installation of appropriate smoke alarms and home sprinkler system, practicing kitchen and oven safety, keeping the water heater at an appropriate temperature (no higher than 120˚F), using sunscreen, and supervising children and individuals with decreased cognitive functioning at all times where heat, appliances, gasoline, hot water, fire, or chemicals are in use(5)
